awd_titl_txt: EDU: Collaborative: Integrating Embedded Systems Security into Computer Engineering and Science Curricula
awd_abstract_narration:
With the advancement of technologies, networked devices become ubiquitous in the society. Such devices are not limited to traditional computers and smart phones, but are increasingly extended to cover a wide variety of embedded systems (ES), such as sensors monitoring bridges, electronics controlling the operation of automobiles and industrial equipment, home medicine devices that are constantly reporting patient health information to doctors. While the wide deployment of networked ES significantly benefits various aspects of human life and society at large, it also poses daunting security challenges that can put national security as well as the privacy of ordinary citizens at risk. Adequately addressing such challenges requires advanced technologies to be developed by industries and ES designers as well as users to be well educated about the security related issues. To facilitate technology development and better educate future designers, this project develops curricula focusing on the unique challenges of the emerging ES security, which has not been systemically covered in existing computer security related curricula that emphasize security in computers and the traditional Internet.

This project makes intellectual contributions through the completion of the following objectives: 1) developing course modules (lecture notes, labs and evaluation questionnaire) to introduce ES security in the layers of software, networking, operating system, architecture, and hardware; 2) integrating the developed material into several existing undergraduate courses at PIs' Universities; 3) establishing a unified ES security course with two versions (computer engineering and computer science versions) by integrating the developed course modules; 4) getting the developed material evaluated by an External Advisory/Review Committee; 5) teaching the developed material using both project-based learning and flipped classroom learning; 6) assessing the proposed teaching methods using formative and summative approaches; 7) broadly disseminating the developed material and promoting diversity in ES security education. Material to be developed will reach over 100 students per year, including many minorities and women.

por.por_cntn:
With the advancement of technologies, networked devices become ubiquitous in the society. Such devices are not limited to traditional computers and smart phones, but are increasingly extended to cover a wide variety of embedded systems (ES). While the wide deployment of networked ES significantly benefits various aspects of human life and society at large, it also poses daunting security challenges that can put national security as well as the privacy of ordinary citizens at risk. Adequately addressing such challenges requires advanced technologies to be developed by industries and ES designers as well as users to be well educated about the security related issues. To facilitate technology development and better educate future designers, this project develops curricula focusing on the unique challenges of the emerging ES security.

The first project outcome is several proposed course modules and its integration to exiting courses at PI universities. For example, architectural related vulnerability such as stack overflow attack has been incorporated into ECE 329 (Computer Organization and Architecture), network induced vulnerability into ECE 422 (Introduction to Data Communication), and FPGA implementation of RSA encryption engine course project in ECE 428 (Programmable ASIC Design).

The second project outcome include lab modules. A semester project design a secure gateway is divided into four milestone in terms of series of labs: secure GUI design, secure socket programming, and secure database implementation and SSL module design. All labs components are using Python, students are recommended to prototype the security gateway using an Intel IoT platform.

Based on individual modules on lectures and labs, the PI has an opportunity to develop and teach a unified embedded systems security design in his ECE 424 class. The course topics include: embedded processor and platform architecture, embedded OS systems, embedded application specification, software development, debugging and performance analysis and optimization, varying security topics of embedded systems. Security vulnerabilities and mitigation techniques are introduced in each topics above. Beside lectures, labs, the course also include student?s paper presentation to study and present varying emerging topics on security and privacy of IoT devices.  Overall students feedback are very positive, particularly from those who eventually work related to embedded system design after graduation. However the PI is feeling quite struggled to cover so many topics in one semester with decent depth, particularly most of his undergraduate students never take any security class before.

To mitigate this problem, the PI have since developed two security classes. The introduction system security focus on more on security principle including crypto, OS security, and software and hardware security with a lot of hands-on labs.  The introduction system security is core course and is the prerequisite to several security related classes including his advance computer security course.  His advanced security class will cover more embedded system security and new emerging topics and semester long projects.

Lastly but not least, more than 100 students have learned embedded systems security in his varying classes. Furthermore, three graduate students has been partially supported and mentored to help develop security course labs and research on advanced network embedded system design such as many-field packet classification using machine learning.
